HOOK: Your buyer just asked if they could write a letter to the seller's dead mother. [ON-SCREEN: "Write a letter to the seller's DEAD MOTHER"]

BRAND INTRO: "This is D.J. Paris with Keeping It Real Podcast, and this is your agent tip of the day."

SETUP: Bestselling novelist Marisa Kashino thought she was writing fiction about buyers going unhinged in competitive markets. Then a Seattle agent told her that dead mother letter story actually happened. [ON-SCREEN: "This actually happened"] You've got buyers losing their minds after getting outbid for the eleventh time, two years of house hunting, watching their biggest investment slip away again and again. [ON-SCREEN: "Outbid 11 times in 2 years"]
[15-SEC RE-HOOK]: But here's what agents told Marisa they're really dealing with.

INSIGHT: She heard about buyers offering to pay for the seller's divorce attorney. Promising to name their baby after the seller. [ON-SCREEN: "Name their baby after the seller"] One guy tried to buy the house next door just to be closer. In her book, the character stalks owners at grocery stores, shows up at their kid's soccer games. [ON-SCREEN: "Stalking at soccer games"] As Marisa puts it: "It's really how far would someone go to get the house, right?" You're not managing transactions ‚Äî you're managing people at their absolute breaking point. [ON-SCREEN: "Managing people at breaking point"]

REFRAME: Every agent has that one buyer story. The uninvited house visits. The cash offers they didn't actually have. The ones that made you wonder if you should've been a therapist instead. That's not bad clients ‚Äî that's what happens when you don't draw the line early.

CTA: "Before your next buyer consultation, ask this: 'What's the craziest thing you've considered doing to get a house?' ‚Äî are you asking boundary questions like this?"

CLOSE: "See you next time."
